content.body: MDN says this, but testing in the wild seems to suggest otherwise in some scenarios.
Luca Casonato: Chrome has had a bug for a long time where that was not the case, but I think it's being fixed per blink-dev
content.formatted_body: Luca Casonato: Chrome has had a bug for a long time where that was not the case, but I think it's being fixed per blink-dev

content.body: Ah, that explains it. Thanks
For anyone interested, this is the bug to track https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1253267

Is request's `user-activation` bit actually used anywhere? It doesn't seem to be referenced anywhere in HTML or Fetch, besides being set in https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#navigating-across-documents:concept-request-user-activation. But I don't think it is ever read?
content.formatted_body: Is request's user-activation bit actually used anywhere? It doesn't seem to be referenced anywhere in HTML or Fetch, besides being set in https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#navigating-across-documents:concept-request-user-activation. But I don't think it is ever read?

content.body: Kinda looks like we just use the `hasTransientActivation` boolean everywhere instead of the request bit
content.formatted_body: Kinda looks like we just use the hasTransientActivation boolean everywhere instead of the request bit

content.body: Dominic Farolino: it's read by the Sec-Fetch headers
content.formatted_body: Dominic Farolino: it's read by the Sec-Fetch headers

content.body: Perhaps that should be clarified in a note or some such as it's indeed somewhat opaque
annevk: Are you saying request's user-activation bit is ready by Sec-Fetch headers, or `hasTransientActivation` is? The former only has a single reference in HTML I think
content.formatted_body: annevk: Are you saying request's user-activation bit is ready by Sec-Fetch headers, or hasTransientActivation is? The former only has a single reference in HTML I think
